Expectation1: Prepare and maintain financial records accurately.
Situation1: An external auditor has just requested specific financial statements for an immediate review.
Expectation2: Follow all instructions provided by election officials
Situation2: A poll worker requests that the voter re-sign a smudged envelope so the ballot will not risk rejection later.
Story:
I was hunched over my desk, double-checking the quarterly reports when the external auditor’s email popped up: “Please send the reconciled statements by noon.” My heart skipped. I knew the numbers had to be flawless—one error could mean hours of backtracking and a tarnished reputation. I glanced at the clock. It was almost time for my lunch break, which I’d planned to use for voting in the local election. I grabbed my coat and hurried to the polling station, financial statements still swirling in my mind.

At the booth, I carefully filled out my ballot, but as I handed it over, the poll worker frowned. “The envelope’s signature is smudged. Please re-sign so your vote isn’t rejected.” I hesitated, thinking of the auditor’s deadline and the expectation to follow every election instruction precisely. My mind raced: if I delayed, the auditor might question my reliability; if I rushed, my vote might not count. The weight of both roles pressed on me, each demanding my full attention, and I stood there, pen in hand, torn between professional duty and civic responsibility.
